newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: MARADONA BACKS DOWN ON MANAGER'S DRUG BUST THREAT.
newsitem.headline: MARADONA BACKS DOWN ON MANAGER'S DRUG BUST THREAT.

text.p: Soccer star Diego Maradona backed down on Thursday from a threat to reveal murky "political and economic interests" behind his manager's arrest on cocaine dealing charges, and promised to keep quiet.

The hero of Argentina's 1986 World Cup title, himself a cocaine addict, made a veiled apology to the judge who had his manager, Guillermo Coppola, arrested after police found a pound (500 grams) of cocaine in a flower pot at his apartment.

"I trust in the justice system and especially Judge Hernan Bernasconi and will cooperate fully to clear up the matter he is investigating and avoid making his job more difficult," the 36-year-old player said in a statement put out by his lawyers.

A day earlier Maradona had published an open letter in the press vowing to "head a campaign to make all those responsible for this injustice pay," and reveal "hidden dark political and economic interests" behind Coppola's arrest and imprisonment.

Maradona's silver-haired 49-year-old manager and close friend, arrested two weeks ago along with Maradona's brother-in-law Gabriel Esposito, ex-soccer international Alberto Tarantini and others, insisted the drugs were planted.
Coppola told the judge that after he left his home for the last time during a party the Saturday before the raid, Maradona and three women partied there until late on Sunday.
Maradona, due to give evidence next week, said he had kept quiet since the case began and would resume his silence.

"Diego never meant to sound threatening and after the last communique was issued, Diego understood its tone was not what he intended," his lawyer Daniel Bolotnicoff told reporters. He described Maradona as "very distressed" at Coppola's plight.
Maradona, once the world's most expensive player but in decline since a 15-month drugs ban after the U.S. World Cup, has not played for Buenos Aires' Boca Juniors since August.

He is very fond of Coppola, but many Argentines blame the playboy manager for Maradona's drug habit, which put him in a Swiss clinic for 10 days last month. Days later he went berserk in a Spanish hotel and smashed up the lobby.

The case was embarrassing the Argentine government. Coppola not only visited President Carlos Menem's Olivos residence with Maradona, but was a friend of Menem's late son Carlitos and Menem's private secretary Ramon Hernandez.
